pageDescription: Math actions are useful for performing math operations on bots and numbers.

comment.shortText: Calculates the absolute value of the given number. That is, the number without its sign.

tags.text:
Calculate the absolute value for the number -42.
const _42 = math.abs(-42);

comment.shortText: the number that the absolute value should be calculated for.
Calculates the absolute value of the given number. That is, the number without its sign.

tags.text:
Calculate the absolute value for the number -42.

comment.shortText: Mathematically adds the given vectors to each other and returns the sum result.
comment.text:
A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: the vectors that should be added together.
Mathematically adds the given vectors to each other and returns the sum result.
comment.text:
A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: Determines if the given numbers are within 2 decimal places of each other.
comment.text:
Because [JavaScript numbers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number) have limited precision, some calculations cannot be represented like they can in normal math.
For example, `1/3` is `0.3333...` but in JavaScript `1/3` gives `0.33333333333333331483`.
This inaccuracy can cause problems when many calculations are done, which can cause numbers that appear to be the same to actually be different.

The solution is to check the difference between two numbers to see if it is below some arbitrary threshold.
In this case, the threshold is `0.005`.

comment.shortText: the first number to check.
the second number to check.
Determines if the given numbers are within 2 decimal places of each other.
comment.text:
Because [JavaScript numbers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number) have limited precision, some calculations cannot be represented like they can in normal math.
For example, `1/3` is `0.3333...` but in JavaScript `1/3` gives `0.33333333333333331483`.
This inaccuracy can cause problems when many calculations are done, which can cause numbers that appear to be the same to actually be different.

The solution is to check the difference between two numbers to see if it is below some arbitrary threshold.
In this case, the threshold is `0.005`.

comment.shortText:
Calculates the arithmetic mean of the given list of values.
That is, the sum of the values divided by the number of values.

tags.text:
Calculate the average of a list of numbers.
const average = math.avg([4, 54.2, 31]);

Calculate the average #age of all the bots.
const averageAge = math.avg(getBotTagValues('#age'));

comment.shortText:
The value that should be averaged.
            If it is a list, then the result will be sum(list)/list.length.
            If it is not a list, then the result will be the value converted to a number.

comment.shortText: Converts the given number of [degrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degree_(angle)) to [radians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radian) and returns the result.
comment.text: This operation is equivalent to `radians = degrees * (Math.PI / 180)`.

tags.text:
Get the number of radians for a 90 degree angle
const radians = math.degreesToRadians(90);

comment.shortText: the number of degrees that should be converted to radians.
Converts the given number of [degrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degree_(angle)) to [radians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radian) and returns the result.
comment.text: This operation is equivalent to `radians = degrees * (Math.PI / 180)`.

comment.shortText:
Calculates the 3D position offset for the given anchor point and returns it.
This is essentially [`experiment.getAnchorPointPosition(bot, dimension, anchorPoint)`](ref:experiment.getAnchorPointPosition) but without the bot's position/scale applied.
the anchor point that should be calculated. Can be any valid [`#anchorPoint`](tags:anchorPoint) value.

Calculates the 3D position offset for the given anchor point and returns it.
This is essentially {@link experiment.getAnchorPointPosition} but without the bot's position/scale applied.
Gets the forward direction for the given rotation.
comment.text: Useful for finding where a bot would be pointing if it has a custom rotation.

comment.shortText: The rotation that the pointer has represented in radians.
Gets the forward direction for the given rotation.
comment.text: Useful for finding where a bot would be pointing if it has a custom rotation.

comment.shortText:
Creates a new random number generator from the given seed and returns it.
Because of how random number generators work, generators created with the same seed will return the same sequence of random numbers.

the number or string that should be used as the seed value for the random number generator.
If omitted, then a seed will be chosen in a somewhat unpredictable manner.

Creates a new random number generator from the given seed and returns it.
Because of how random number generators work, generators created with the same seed will return the same sequence of random numbers.

Calculates the 3D point that a ray starting at the given origin point and traveling in the given direction intersects the grid portal ground plane.
Returns null if the ray does not intersect the ground plane.
comment.text: Useful for calculating where on the ground something is pointing.

comment.shortText: the 3D point that the ray should start at.
the direction that the ray is traveling along.

the normal vector that the plane should use.
For 2D planes, the normal vector is the 3D direction that is perpendicular to the the surface of the plane.
For example, a plane that covers the entire XY surface has a normal vector equal to `➡️0,0,1`, while a plane that covers the YZ surface has a normal vector equal to `➡️1,0,0`.
This parameter defaults to `➡️0,0,1`.
the 3D position that the center of the plane should travel through. Defaults to `➡️0,0,0`.

Calculates the 3D point that a ray starting at the given origin point and traveling in the given direction intersects the grid portal ground plane.
Returns null if the ray does not intersect the ground plane.
comment.text: Useful for calculating where on the ground something is pointing.

comment.shortText: Mathematically negates the given vector and returns the result.
comment.text:
A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: Normalizes the given vector. The result is a vector that has the same direction as the given vector but has a length/magnitude of 1.
comment.text:
Mathemematically, this is the same as finding the [`math.vectorLength(vector)`](ref:math.vectorLength) and dividing each component in the vector by it.

A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: the vector that should be normalized.
Normalizes the given vector. The result is a vector that has the same direction as the given vector but has a length/magnitude of 1.
comment.text:
Mathemematically, this is the same as finding the {@link math.vectorLength} and dividing each component in the vector by it.

A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.

comment.shortText: Converts the given number of [radians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radian) to [degrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degree_(angle)) and returns the result.
comment.text: This operation is equivalent to `degrees = radians * (180 / Math.PI)`.

tags.text:
Get the number of degrees for a Math.PI / 2 angle
const degrees = math.radiansToDegrees(Math.PI / 2);

comment.shortText: the number of radians that should be converted to degrees.

comment.shortText: Generates a random number between the given minimum and maximum values.

tags.text:
Generate a random number between 0 and Math.PI.
const number = math.random(0, Math.PI);

comment.shortText: The smallest allowed value.
The largest allowed value.

Generate a random number between 0 and Math.PI.

comment.shortText: Generates a random integer number between the given minimum and maximum values.

tags.text:
Generate a random number between 5 and 10.

comment.shortText: Multiplies each property of the given vector by the given scale and returns the result.
comment.text:
A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: the vector that should be scaled.
the number that the vector should be multiplied by.
Multiplies each property of the given vector by the given scale and returns the result.
comment.text:
A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: Sets the seed that should be used for the random numbers generated with [`math.randomInt(min, max)`](ref:math.randomInt) and [`math.random(min, max)`](ref:math.random).

the number or string that should be used as the seed value for the internal random number generator.
If null is provided, then a seed will be chosen in a somewhat unpredictable manner.
Sets the seed that should be used for the random numbers generated with {@link math.randomInt} and {@link math.random}.

comment.shortText: Calculates the [standard deviation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_deviation for the given list of values.

tags.text:
Calculate the standard deviation of a list of numbers.
const standardDeviation = math.stdDev([2, 97, 745]);

Calculate the standard deviation of the #age of all the bots.
const ageDeviation = math.stdDev(getBotTagValues('#age'));

comment.shortText: Calculates the numerical sum of the given values.
comment.text:
If any value in the list is not a number, it will be converted to one.
If the given value is not an array, then it will be converted to a number and returned.

tags.text:
Calculate the sum of a list of numbers.
const total = math.sum([92, 123, 21]);

Calculate the total #age of all the bots.
const totalAge = math.sum(getBotTagValues('#age'));
Math actions are useful for performing math operations on bots and numbers.

comment.shortText:
the list of values that should be summed up. If any value in the list is not a number, it will be converted to one.
If the list is not actually a list, then it will be converted to a number and returned.

comment.shortText: Calculates the length (i.e. magnitude) of the given vector.
comment.text:
Mathemematically, this is equivalent to `length = sqrt(sum(components.map(c => c * c)))`. As a consequence, vectors that are normalized always have a length of 1.

A vector is a group of numbers which represents a specific point in 2D/3D/4D/etc. space.
For example, the vector `{ x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }` represents the point `(1, 2, 3)` in 3D space where `x`, `y`, and `z` are the names of the dimensions (or axes).

comment.shortText: the vector to calculate the length of.
Calculates the length (i.e. magnitude) of the given vector.
comment.text:
Mathemematically, this is equivalent to `length = sqrt(sum(components.map(c => c * c)))`. As a consequence, vectors that are normalized always have a length of 1.
